title: 111_hr1701
content: The "PTSD/TBI Guaranteed Review For Heroes Act" may be cited as the short title. It establishes a Special Review Board. The "PTSD/TBI Guaranteed Review For Heroes Act" establishes a Special Review Board within the Office of the Secretary of Defense to review the discharge or dismissal of covered individuals with post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury. The board must consist of at least five members, including a health care professional relevant to the matter being reviewed. The Special Review Board can review the discharge or dismissal of covered individuals with post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury. Requests for review must be made within 15 years of discharge. The review considers the individual's actions before and after deployment, treatment received for PTSD/TBI, and any other evidence presented. Covered individuals can appear before the board in person or with counsel. The Special Review Board can review the discharge or dismissal of covered individuals with PTSD or TBI. Requests for review must be made within 15 years of discharge. Covered individuals may appear before the board in person or with counsel. If the special review board reviews the discharge, a service review agency may not review it. If a Member of Congress requests a review and it is denied, the board must notify the Member of Congress. The board may change the discharge to honorable after a review. The Secretary concerned shall correct records. The Secretary concerned corrects military records of covered individuals as per changes made by the special review board. Regulations for this section are set by the Secretary of Defense, including deadlines for required reviews. A covered individual is a former Armed Forces member deployed in a contingency operation, discharged under general or other than honorable conditions, and diagnosed with a health condition. The text chunk provides definitions for terms like "health care professional," "Member of Congress," and "service review agency" in relation to correcting military records of covered individuals with health conditions like post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury. SEC. 3. Examination and evaluation of members with post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury. Referral to Physical Evaluation Board for members with post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury is mandated. The evaluation must be conducted by a physician or health care professional, and separation from the Armed Forces is prohibited until the evaluation results are considered. The amendment to Title 10 of the United States Code mandates evaluation for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder or Traumatic Brain Injury by a physical evaluation board. If deemed unfit, the member will be retired or separated, and if fit, the board's findings will be considered in any separation from the Armed Forces.
